docs.lead_paragraph: Patients with the agonizing and intractable pain of sickle cell disease should get better, more consistent relief because of new treatment guidelines that call for comprehensive management of the pain, experts say. The guidelines, intended for doctors, nurses and other health professionals who treat sickle cell disease, call for aggressive use of drugs along with behavioral, psychological and physical therapies to relieve patients' suffering.

headline.main: Aggressive Pain Control Encouraged In Sickle Cell

docs.abstract: Experts say that patients with agonizing and intractable pain of sickle cell disease should get better, more consistent relief because of new treatment guidelines that call for comprehensive management of pain; guidelines, intended for doctors, nurses and other health professionals who treat sickle cell disease, call for aggressive use of drugs along with behavioral, psychological and physical therapies to relieve patients' suffering; drawing illustrates 'Oucher,' table that correlates facial expressions with pain (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As the fall soccer season begins, legions of schoolchildren are taking to the fields with images of the stunning World Cup victory by the United States women's team still fresh in their minds. But many doctors have other matters on their minds: how to make soccer safer for children in light of recent reports linking it to repeated concussions and diminished mental functioning. A central question surrounds the practice of heading, or hitting the ball with the head. In a two-year study of 60 soccer players ages 11 to 14 in Ann Arbor, Mich., Dr. David Janda, an orthopedic surgeon, found that nearly half had symptoms of concussion: blurred or double vision, headaches, nausea and ringing in the ears. The symptoms were most common in the children who headed the ball most often, Dr. Janda said.

headline.main: New Soccer Season and New Safety Concern

docs.abstract: Many doctors are concerned about how to make soccer safer for children in light of recent reports linking it to repeated concussions and diminished mental functioning; central question surrounds practice of heading, or hitting ball with head; two-year study of of 60 soccer players ages 11 to 14 in Ann Arbor, Mich, finds that nearly half have symptoms of concussion: blurred or double vision, headaches, nausea and ringing in ears; symptoms are most common in children who headed ball most often (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Four years ago, two scientists announced that they had found a way to repair a fundamental defect in the brains of children and adults who fail to learn to read. They published articles in leading scientific journals, raised venture capital and formed a company to make their technique available to children, parents, teachers and schools across the nation. Billed as an entirely new way to treat dyslexia, the technique uses repeated and fast-paced computer-generated exercises meant to make nerve cells work faster. After several weeks, circuits in the brain are reorganized in ways that are supposed to make it easier to learn to read.

headline.main: Verdict Still Not In on Dyslexia Therapy

docs.abstract: New therapy for treating dyslexia, which involves reorganizing circuits in brain in ways that are supposed to make it easier to read, has yet to be evaluated by independent scientists; virtually all research on how well it works has been carried out by Scientific Learning Inc of Berkeley, Calif, company founded by Drs Paula Tallal and Mike Merzenich, who developed therapy and founded company to market it; drawings (M)
docs.snippet: Four years ago, two scientists announced that they had found a way to repair a fundamental defect in the brains of children and adults who fail to learn to read. They published articles in leading scientific journals, raised venture capital and...

docs.lead_paragraph: Annie Oakley did most of her dead-eye shooting in the healthy outdoors. But teen-agers and others who want to emulate her need to be concerned about the hazards of lead exposure at indoor firing ranges. In the Sept. 9 issue of The New England Journal of Medicine, Dr. Michael Shannon, director of the Pediatric Environmental Health Center at Children's Hospital in Boston, reported the cases of four girls, ages 14 to 16, who had significant lead poisoning. The condition can damage the kidneys, bone marrow and nervous system and can harm a fetus during pregnancy.

headline.main: Indoor Shooters, Look Out for the Lead

docs.abstract: Lead poisoning emerges as hazard for young people at indoor firing ranges (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Dr. Ronald Epstein counseled a patient who was considering genetic screening for breast cancer, he confronted questions his medical knowledge had not equipped him to address. What difference would knowing the results make? How much was the patient guided by fear and depression? What approach would be most helpful? What helped him, he wrote in the Sept. 1 issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association, was what he called ''mindful practice.'' In the article, he urged fellow doctors to make ''attending to the ordinary, the obvious and the present'' part of their practice.

headline.main: Learning to See Beyond a Patient's Chart

docs.abstract: Dr Ronald Epstein, writing in Journal of American Medical Assn, urges fellow doctors to make 'attending to the ordinary, the obvious and the present' part of their practice; holds too often doctors focus on technical aspects of medical care at expense of reflection, self-awareness and sensitivity to patients' feelings and values; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: If you ever think you're about to fall down laughing -- say, when you hear that old knee-slapper about the Belgians and their extra-long moving vans -- scientists may now be able to tell you why. Laughter, it turns out, seems to trigger a reflex that can bring many of the muscles of the body to the point of collapse. The phenomenon can actually be measured by sending electric signals through the muscles and gauging their response.

headline.main: How Muscles Can Go Weak With Laughter

docs.abstract: Researchers in Netherlands find that laughter seems to trigger a reflex that can bring many of body's muscles to point of collapse (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: People in their 50's and older who feel cramping or pain in their legs while walking may dismiss the symptoms as inevitable signs of aging. But in fact, they are the common signs of peripheral vascular disease, which is caused by blockages in leg arteries that in turn increase the risk of heart disease and lead to 100,000 leg amputations each year in the United States, according to the Society of Cardiovascular and Interventional Radiology, a medical organization.

headline.main: Leg Pains, Bad Veins and Free Screenings

docs.abstract: Hospital and health-care centers across country are offering free screenings for peripheral vascular disease, which is caused by blockages in leg arteries that in turn increase risk of heart disease and lead to 100,000 leg amputations each year (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers at the Mayo Clinic who were looking for the most common cause of chronic sinus infections say they have found what they were seeking -- and it was not the culprit most doctors had expected. Until recently, doctors thought the disease was usually a bacterial infection, with perhaps 6 percent of cases caused by a reaction to fungus. But after a two-year study of 210 chronic sinusitis patients, the researchers found that more than 90 percent of the cases arose from an immune-system response to a common fungus.
docs.abstract: Researchers at the Mayo Clinic find that more than 90 percent of chronic sinus infections studied arose from immune-system response to a common fungus (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Mark Shulman, first fitted for glasses at age 5, was never happy about his dependence on them. They would fog up in winter or get clouded with sweat in summer when he pursued the outdoor activities he loved. To see clearly when he did his daily swim, he needed prescription goggles. Contact lenses didn't work for him. So at age 61 he invested about $5,000 in laser surgery to correct his myopia and astigmatisms by reshaping his corneas and to enable him to do everything but read without glasses. Dr. Shulman, a retired professor of meteorology living in Woodstock, N.Y., couldn't be more delighted. His distance vision is now better than 20/20. He sees well at night and can drive without glasses despite a slight loss of depth perception.

headline.main: Promise and Risks of Laser Eye Surgery

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on pros and cons of laser eye surgery to correct myopia and astigmatisms; some people who have had laser eye surgery say they were not adequately warned of possible aftereffects, like seeing halos around lights; photos (M)
